term_definitions.definition: A coordinated setup involving technology, people, and procedures designed to organize and deliver useful content for business decision-making.
A comprehensive software suite that manages and connects all major operations of a business through a central database.
The key departments within a company, each specializing in a distinct set of responsibilities to support overall goals.
A specific task or activity carried out by a particular department within a company structure.
A coordinated sequence of tasks that takes inputs and produces results that fulfill organizational or customer needs.
A resource such as data, materials, or labor used as the starting point in a series of operational steps.
The final product or service produced through operational activities and delivered to the end recipient.
A recipient of services or outputs who operates within the same organization that provides them.
A purchaser or user of goods or services who is not part of the organization offering them.
A digital framework that allows seamless and non-redundant data flow across all organizational departments.
The organizational unit responsible for promoting offerings, handling customer interactions, and planning sales strategies.
The area responsible for managing the flow of materials and goods from suppliers to customers efficiently.
The function that tracks and manages financial transactions, expenditures, and reporting across a business.
The team or system focused on acquiring talent, overseeing training, and ensuring compliance with employment standards.
A projection used to estimate upcoming demand for products based on past performance and market trends.
Unprocessed information collected from operations that has yet to be organized or interpreted.
A calculated figure representing the expense required to make a single item or unit of a product.
Data that reflects how resources like time, money, and materials have been consumed by a business.
The practice of ensuring that a company’s actions meet required legal and ethical standards.
Data that becomes instantly accessible as operations unfold, providing current and accurate updates.
A centralized platform designed to enable data sharing across various business operations and managerial levels.
A suite of integrated applications used to manage key processes and ensure consistency across departments.
An outdated system structure where departments operate independently with minimal data integration.
A network structure that allows multiple users to access shared resources and data across local systems.
A principle that observes a consistent doubling of computational capacity approximately every 18 months.
An early solution for planning inventory and production needs using computerized systems.
A system for exchanging standard business documents directly between organizations' computers.
An approach that facilitates information flow across operational layers without the need for upper-level approval.
An arrangement in which a third party provides and manages computing infrastructure and software access.
A system type focused on helping an organization coordinate planning and implementation activities enterprise-wide.
Technology used to improve the performance of individual departments within an organization.
A tool for recording and processing day-to-day transactions such as inventory updates or payroll entries.
A method where transactions are collected and processed together at a later time instead of instantly.
A system that handles and records each transaction as it occurs, providing immediate data updates.
Software used to manage interactions and data associated with existing and prospective customers.
A solution that tracks information and activities related to a product from initial concept to disposal.
A tool used to digitally create and refine technical designs and blueprints of physical products.
A system that uses simulations and analysis to test how well a component or product performs.
Software that controls machines and production lines to produce parts according to digital designs.
A form of production involving individual, countable items such as electronics or vehicles.
A type of manufacturing where the output is the result of chemical transformation and cannot be easily separated into parts.
A system that monitors and evaluates the condition of materials or products throughout the manufacturing process.
A visual tool used to display the interactions between external users and a system’s functionalities.
A representation of data structures showing types of objects and their relationships in a static view.
A snapshot illustrating specific instances of system objects and their links at a single point in time.
A flow-based representation used to model the order and coordination of actions within a process.
A diagram that captures the order and timing of message exchanges between users and system parts.
A model that tracks how an item or system responds to internal changes or external stimuli over time.
A schematic that shows how different parts of a system are organized and how they interact.
A structural visualization that groups related system components into higher-level organizational units.
A layout that maps where system software components are installed across physical hardware nodes.
A diagram that exposes the inner structure of a class or object, showing what it contains and how parts relate.
A process used to identify system-triggering conditions and associate them with specific system behaviors.
The smallest complete response by a system to an external trigger, providing measurable value.
A guideline used during analysis that ignores system limitations in order to focus on functional requirements.
The steps that record customer requests, check availability, calculate prices, and finalize the terms of a transaction.
A real-time system check that evaluates current inventory and production capacity to confirm delivery dates.
A formal document provided to a potential buyer offering prices and terms before an order is placed.
A document that details the items included in a shipment and accompanies goods sent to customers.
A code used to authorize and track returned merchandise for proper credit and processing.
A set of tools and strategies for managing all customer interactions to improve business relationships.
The set of activities associated with managing workforce tasks like hiring, training, and compensation.
A strategy for identifying and preparing future leaders to fill key positions when they become vacant.
A process in which employee compensation is calculated, deductions are applied, and payment is finalized.
A process involving request, approval, and coordination of business travel within an organization.
An approach where managers and employees agree on goals and assess performance based on results.
A coordinated set of activities to determine what and when to produce based on demand and capacity.
A projection used to estimate future product demand based on historical data and marketing plans.
A process that balances expected market demand with the organization's production capacity.
A link between demand planning and execution, producing a master schedule of what and when to produce.
A structured list of components and materials required to manufacture a finished product.
A calculation method that determines what materials are needed and when based on production schedules.
A method for planning how long and when each product should be produced to minimize costs.
A methodology in ERP systems used to calculate the cost of making a product using a specific set of assumptions.
A costing approach that assigns indirect costs to products based on activities that generate those costs.
The main accounting record where all business transactions are posted and summarized.
The total amount of money owed to a company by its customers for goods or services delivered.
The method of calculating the value of products in stock, including materials, labor, and overhead.
A system feature that restricts user actions based on predefined monetary or access limits.
A digital reporting standard used to exchange financial data in a structured, machine-readable format.
A technique that represents the flow and structure of a process to support understanding and improvement.
The process of identifying, documenting, and managing the features that a system must have to meet business needs.
A specific behavior or function that a system must perform to fulfill user expectations.
A constraint or quality attribute such as security, scalability, or performance that affects how a system operates.
A structured method used to discover stakeholder needs through various data collection techniques.
A structured guide used before, during, and after a stakeholder conversation to ensure all topics are covered effectively.
A visual or symbolic representation used to simplify and communicate aspects of a system or process.
A visual format that illustrates one or more operational procedures within a business environment.
A type of diagram that displays how inputs are processed into outputs through various stages.
A diagram that outlines interactions between users and a system, typically representing user scenarios.
A model that shows how components of a system interact in sequence over time.
A standardized set of symbols and notations used to represent software systems visually.
An assessment to determine whether the correct needs and objectives have been identified.
A process for checking if documented requirements are stated clearly and accurately.
A diagram that uses symbols to visually map the steps or decisions in a workflow or process.
A form of visual documentation that highlights steps in an existing workflow to identify improvement opportunities.
A flowchart format that displays tasks aligned with the person or role responsible for each step.
A simplified model of a process using only events and functions to align with ERP system structures.
A UML diagram that shows the sequence and coordination of actions performed by users or systems.
A method of analyzing each step in a process to determine how much it contributes to delivering value.
A computer-aided simulation technique used to predict outcomes of proposed changes to a process.
A digital system that automates the sequence, participants, and documentation of business tasks.
A discipline focused on managing human responses and adaptation to structural or technological changes in a company.

chapters.chapter_title: Business Intelligence, Mobile Computing, and the Cloud

term_definitions.definition: A technology used to track items using small radio-powered devices, often used in supply chain management.
A small device with a microprocessor and antenna that can be attached to an object for wireless identification.
A device that emits radio waves to detect and communicate with identification tags wirelessly.
A collection of tools and technologies that analyze large volumes of data to support business decision-making.
A technique that extracts patterns and useful insights from large datasets using statistical and computational methods.
A method of setting organizational goals and measuring performance against them to improve strategic outcomes.
A set of practices aimed at ensuring an organization operates within legal and ethical boundaries.
A storage solution optimized for the efficient handling and analysis of large-scale, structured data.
A discipline that oversees how information is collected, managed, and used as a strategic business asset.
A computing approach that stores large datasets directly in memory for faster analysis and processing.
The use of portable devices and wireless connectivity to access and interact with data and applications.
A model for delivering software and services over the internet rather than through local infrastructure.
An architectural approach that enables services to be reused and integrated across business applications.
A delivery model in which software is hosted remotely and accessed by users via the internet.
Lower upfront costs, faster implementation, reduced need for in-house technical expertise, and simpler support.
Security risks, limited customization, dependency on internet connectivity, and potential vendor lock-in.
A financial method that converts future cash flows into present value to evaluate the profitability of investments.
The minimum rate of return a company expects to earn when investing in a project, used in NPV calculations.
The coordinated planning and operation of IT processes to meet business needs effectively and efficiently.
A structured approach for managing services from conception through retirement, including strategy, design, transition, operation, and improvement.
The phase focused on defining market opportunities and converting them into services that offer value to customers.
The stage where new or modified services are planned and specified before moving into operation.
The process of managing all tasks associated with the introduction and modification of services into the live environment.
The phase that ensures services are delivered effectively and meet agreed performance standards.
A continuous process of assessing and enhancing IT services to ensure they remain aligned with evolving business needs.
The aspect of a service that meets a specific need or purpose, making it 'fit for purpose'.
The aspect of a service that ensures it is available when needed, making it 'fit for use'.
A documented agreement that outlines expected service levels between a provider and customer.
An unplanned disruption to an IT service or a reduction in its quality.
The underlying cause of one or more incidents, often requiring deeper analysis to resolve.
An identified cause of a problem that has a known workaround or solution, stored for future reference.
A formal process that ensures standardized handling of changes to reduce risks and disruption.
A formal proposal submitted to initiate a change in IT services or infrastructure.
A component that needs to be managed in order to deliver an IT service, excluding people.
A database or repository listing all live services provided to customers and their current status.
The probability that a system will function as expected during scheduled time.
The likelihood that a system will perform consistently under defined conditions for a set time.
A metric showing the average time between system failures.
A measure of how long it takes to repair a system and restore service after a failure.
A group of representatives who evaluate, approve, or reject proposed changes.
A function that acts as a single point of contact for users, handling incidents and service requests.
A comprehensive view of all services managed by a provider, including those in development and retired.
A predefined bundle of services and service level options customized to specific customer needs.
A structured methodology for identifying, analyzing, and implementing service improvements.
A measurable element used to evaluate the success or performance of a process or service.
A key area of focus that must be achieved for a process or project to be successful.
A cycle for continuous improvement involving planning, executing, monitoring, and refining actions.
